growing.sun: Full sun to partial shade (prefers some afternoon shade in hot climates)
growing.water: Moderate; prefers evenly moist soil but tolerates short dry spells once established
growing.soil: Rich, well-drained soil with good organic matter

planting.whenToPlant: Spring after danger of frost, or early fall in mild climates
planting.propagation: Seeds, division, or softwood cuttings; division is fast and reliable
planting.depth: Sow seeds on surface or barely cover (~1/8 inch); divisions at same depth as original plant

careAndMaintenance.pruning: Cut back by half after flowering to encourage fresh growth and prevent legginess
careAndMaintenance.overwintering: Hardy in zones 4-9; mulch in cold areas to protect roots

harvestingAndUsage.whenToHarvest: Before or at the start of flowering for best flavor and medicinal properties
harvestingAndUsage.howToHarvest: Snip leaves and stems as needed; avoid cutting more than one-third at a time to allow regrowth
harvestingAndUsage.preservation: Best used fresh; can be dried (loses some potency) or frozen in ice cubes or oil
harvestingAndUsage.edibleOrToxic: Entire plant is edible and safe; mild and lemony flavor
harvestingAndUsage.culinary: Used fresh in salads, desserts, teas, syrups, and to flavor fish and poultry dishes; also used in herb butters and vinegars

medicinal.Calming & Nervous System Support: Traditionally used to ease anxiety, stress, and mild insomnia; often taken as a tea or tincture.
medicinal.Digestive Aid: Helps relieve indigestion, bloating, and gas; mild antispasmodic effects.
medicinal.Antiviral & Immune Support: Used externally and internally for cold sores (herpes simplex virus); also used to support immune health during colds and flu.
medicinal.Cognitive Support: Historically valued for improving mood and mental clarity.

harvestingAndUsage.aromatic: Fresh, citrusy scent with sweet lemon undertones; used in potpourri, sachets, and herbal pillows

ecologicalInfo.wildlifeResistance: Generally deer-resistant due to strong lemon scent

funFacts: Lemon balm was called the 'elixir of life' by Paracelsus, a 16th-century physician.
Historically planted near bee hives to encourage bees to stay and produce honey.
Its name, Melissa, means 'honeybee' in Greek.
